recommended_movies: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)
When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts (2006)

Things You Can Tell Just by Looking at Her (2000)

simulated_ratings.title: Passion of the Christ, The (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Viscerally powerful, but the relentless brutality dampens the spiritual nuance for me.

simulated_ratings.title: In the Bedroom (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A quietly devastating family tragedy with performances that linger.

simulated_ratings.title: Shopgirl (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wistful and tender, though its romantic triangle feels a touch thin.

simulated_ratings.title: Open Water (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Effective minimalist dread, but a bit one-note once the premise locks in.

simulated_ratings.title: Snow Falling on Cedars (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeous and moody, with a resonance in its themes of prejudice and memory.

simulated_ratings.title: American, The (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A restrained, patient character study of a killer that I found absorbing.

simulated_ratings.title: Girl with a Pearl Earring (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, painterly filmmaking that turns restraint into intrigue.

simulated_ratings.title: Monster's Ball (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Raw and empathetic, tough to watch yet ultimately humane.

simulated_ratings.title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rousing, meticulously crafted seafaring adventure with real human stakes.

simulated_ratings.title: Schindler's List (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Profound, harrowing, and essential—craft and conscience in rare harmony.

simulated_ratings.title: East-West (Est-ouest) (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A gripping portrait of life under suspicion, tinged with aching longing.

simulated_ratings.title: Apocalypto (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless and immersive survival tale whose intensity carries it.

simulated_ratings.title: Inconvenient Truth, An (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clear, urgent, and persuasive—documentary advocacy done right.

simulated_ratings.title: Dances with Wolves (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Expansive and heartfelt frontier epic that earns its sweep.

simulated_ratings.title: Rabbit-Proof Fence (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spare, moving, and quietly triumphant against cruel odds.

simulated_ratings.title: Army of Crime (L'armée du crime) (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stirring resistance drama with a sharp eye for sacrifice and solidarity.

simulated_ratings.title: Italian, The (Italianetz) (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A simple, affecting quest seen through a child’s clear-eyed resolve.

simulated_ratings.title: Piano, The (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Atmospheric, sensual, and uncompromising, anchored by potent emotion.

simulated_ratings.title: Akeelah and the Bee (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Uplifting and sincere, if a bit formulaic in its beats.

simulated_ratings.title: Shackleton's Antarctic Adventure (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A lean, inspiring survival chronicle that celebrates endurance.

simulated_ratings.title: The Butterfly Effect 3: Revelations (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A pulpy, twisty ride that never rises above disposable.

simulated_ratings.title: Sea Inside, The (Mar adentro) (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Compassionate and thought-provoking, carried by its moral clarity.

simulated_ratings.title: Grapes of Wrath, The (1940)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A timeless, empathetic ode to dignity amid hardship.

simulated_ratings.title: Dead Man Walking (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sober, humane, and morally engaging without preaching.

simulated_ratings.title: Crying Game, The (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart, tense, and unexpectedly tender beneath the intrigue.

simulated_ratings.title: Things You Can Tell Just by Looking at Her (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle and observant, though its mosaic leaves some stories underfed.

recommended_movies: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles (1994)
Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)
Guinea Pig 5: Mermaid in the Manhole (1988)

simulated_ratings.title: Fountain, The (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeous, audacious meditation on love and mortality that moved me even when its threads felt elusive.

simulated_ratings.title: Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lush, melancholic gothic tale more about loneliness than fangs, which I appreciated.

simulated_ratings.title: Short Cuts (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sprawling but incisive mosaic of flawed lives that accumulates real poignancy.

simulated_ratings.title: Lawn Dogs (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, uneasy class fable that pierces gated-community veneers.

simulated_ratings.title: The Woman King (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rousing, heartfelt historical action with stirring purpose, even if familiar in beats.

simulated_ratings.title: Mother (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A wry, affectionate mother-son tangle that charms more than it dazzles.

simulated_ratings.title: Jeffrey (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Light on its feet yet genuinely compassionate about fear, love, and risk.

simulated_ratings.title: Miss Sloane (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick but gripping issue-driven thriller that scratches my political-ethics itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Mugabe and the White African (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A harrowing, thorny fight for justice that’s both personal and politically sobering.

simulated_ratings.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless, dehumanizing brutality that left me more numb than enlightened.

simulated_ratings.title: Valley of Love (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A spare, sun-bleached meditation on grief that quietly got under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: Peter's Friends (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A bittersweet, cozy reunion piece—uneven, but the warmth and wit land.

simulated_ratings.title: Jersey Girl (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet intentions, but the sentimentality feels prefab and thin.

simulated_ratings.title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sumptuous, macabre fable whose sensory obsession and moral chill fascinated me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Web (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A goofy, disposable tech caper whose lone joke wears thin fast.

simulated_ratings.title: Guinea Pig 5: Mermaid in the Manhole (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grotesque misery-as-aesthetic that I found numbing rather than meaningful.

simulated_ratings.title: Musikanten (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An intriguing, time-slipped brush with Beethoven that favors mood over momentum.

simulated_ratings.title: Bad Behavior (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A thin, cable-grade thriller with a decent hook but little resonance.

simulated_ratings.title: Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Derivative meta-horror that confuses noise for dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Decade Under the Influence, A (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A lively, affectionate primer on the rebel spirit that reshaped American movies.

simulated_ratings.title: Wonder Boys (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A shambling, literate midlife farce with real warmth and rue.

simulated_ratings.title: Delhi-6 (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Vivid and sincere in its portrait of community, if a bit scattered in focus.

simulated_ratings.title: Reinventing Marvin (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An empathetic coming-of-self that finds grace in art’s escape hatch.

simulated_ratings.title: Bound (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tight, stylish neo-noir with crackling chemistry and satisfying reversals.

simulated_ratings.title: Barefoot Gen (Hadashi no Gen) (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Devastating and humane, a searing witness to survival and loss.

simulated_ratings.title: Creature from the Haunted Sea (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A goofy, threadbare creature caper whose charm wears thin.

simulated_ratings.title: The Matchmaker (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, slyly moving cross-generational tale with a haunted undercurrent.

simulated_ratings.title: Innocent Steps (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet and sincere, but the dance-romance beats feel awfully familiar.

simulated_ratings.title: Navigator: A Mediaeval Odyssey, The (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A strange, haunting folk-quest whose leap through time feels genuinely poetic.

simulated_ratings.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sumptuous and operatic, more romantic fever dream than fright—which mostly worked for me.

Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!, The (1988)
Last House on the Left, The (2009)
Apple Dumpling Gang Rides Again, The (1979)

simulated_ratings.title: Loaded Weapon 1 (National Lampoon's Loaded Weapon 1) (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A broad, gag-a-minute spoof that felt more noisy than witty to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Hot Shots! Part Deux (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sillier than smart, but the go-for-broke antics got a few decent laughs.

simulated_ratings.title: Paulie (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet and gently moving, if a bit formulaic in its episodic journey.

simulated_ratings.title: Jason X (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A perfunctory DVD featurette with little to chew on beyond PR gloss.

simulated_ratings.title: Private Parts (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Crude but unexpectedly humanizing, though the juvenilia wears thin.

simulated_ratings.title: Rugrats Movie, The (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Harmless, frenetic kiddie fare that never found much resonance for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Ernest Goes to Camp (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Shrill slapstick with a good heart, but I found it more grating than funny.

simulated_ratings.title: Crucible, The (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A solid, morally charged historical drama that still stings.

simulated_ratings.title: Office Romance (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A warm, wry Soviet workplace romance whose gentle humor won me over.

simulated_ratings.title: Ernest Saves Christmas (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Well-meaning holiday slapstick that mostly tested my patience.

simulated_ratings.title: Homeward Bound: The Incredible Journey (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest, affectionate adventure that hit my soft spot for loyalty and perseverance.

simulated_ratings.title: Martin Lawrence: You So Crazy (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Energetic and candid, but the broad, crude streak wore me out.

simulated_ratings.title: Abbott and Costello Meet Frankenstein (1948)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Old-school horror-comedy with enough charm to overcome its creaks.

simulated_ratings.title: Last House on the Left, The (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An ugly, punitive exercise in brutality that left me numb rather than enlightened.

simulated_ratings.title: Heavyweights (Heavy Weights) (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its kindness peeks through the goofiness, but the satire is too blunt to really land.

simulated_ratings.title: Toxic Avenger, Part II, The (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Troma’s gleeful gross-out chaos is not my brand of fun.

simulated_ratings.title: Brokeback Mountain (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, aching, and humane—a love story that lingers.

simulated_ratings.title: Brady Bunch Movie, The (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A one-joke nostalgia riff that amused in spurts and wore out quickly.

simulated_ratings.title: Pootie Tang (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A shaggy, jokey curio whose absurdity rarely connected for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Black Beauty (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere and compassionate, with a dignified melancholy that I appreciated.

simulated_ratings.title: All Dogs Go to Heaven (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Darkly sweet and uneven, with heart that outpaces its rough edges.

simulated_ratings.title: Apple Dumpling Gang Rides Again, The (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Genial but featherweight slapstick that never rose above cute.

simulated_ratings.title: Bring It On Again (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Formulaic and forgettable, a cheer-off without much to cheer.

simulated_ratings.title: Babe: Pig in the City (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive, bittersweet, and surprisingly affecting in its urban fable mode.

simulated_ratings.title: Critical Care (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp-edged, cynical hospital satire with enough moral bite to engage me.

simulated_ratings.title: Walking Dead, The (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere and somber, but familiar war beats kept it from hitting harder.

recommended_movies: What the #$*! Do We Know!? (a.k.a. What the Bleep Do We Know!?) (2004)
George Carlin: You Are All Diseased (1999)
Mother and the Whore, The (Maman et la putain, La) (1973)
House of Small Cubes, The (Tsumiki no ie) (2008)

simulated_ratings.title: Alone in the Wilderness (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A soothing, quietly inspiring chronicle of self-reliance and the seasons that I found deeply satisfying.

simulated_ratings.title: Connections (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A serviceable Hong Kong caper whose thin characterization kept me at arm's length.

simulated_ratings.title: What the #$*! Do We Know!? (a.k.a. What the Bleep Do We Know!?) (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its mix of drama and pop-science felt murky and glib, leaving me more skeptical than stirred.

simulated_ratings.title: Feels Good Man (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sobering, empathetic cultural autopsy that finds real human stakes in the noise.

simulated_ratings.title: English Patient, The (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lush, aching romance and wartime intrigue that swept me up more often than not.

simulated_ratings.title: George Carlin: You Are All Diseased (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Caustic, incisive rants that hit hard even if the relentless cynicism wears a bit.

simulated_ratings.title: Anne Frank Remembered (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An essential, humane remembrance that moved me with its clarity and care.

simulated_ratings.title: Nixon (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sprawling, engrossing character study that wrestles meaningfully with power and paranoia.

simulated_ratings.title: Sudden Fear (1952)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A taut, elegantly staged noir whose slow-burn tension paid off nicely for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Mother and the Whore, The (Maman et la putain, La) (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Talky, intimate, and emotionally thorny in a way I found bracing if occasionally exhausting.

simulated_ratings.title: Solaris (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A hushed, melancholy sci-fi meditation on grief and connection that worked on me.

simulated_ratings.title: Three Colors: Red (Trois couleurs: Rouge) (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A resonant, humane tapestry of chance and conscience that quietly floored me.

simulated_ratings.title: Unbearable Lightness of Being, The (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sensual, politically shaded romantic entanglements with a lingering sadness I appreciated.

simulated_ratings.title: Baseball (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A lightweight blooper reel that felt disposable next to the richer sports stories I gravitate toward.

simulated_ratings.title: Three Colors: Blue (Trois couleurs: Bleu) (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A luminous, aching study of grief and freedom that left me stirred and contemplative.

simulated_ratings.title: World of Apu, The (Apur Sansar) (1959)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, deeply humane storytelling that seeped into me with quiet power.

simulated_ratings.title: House of Small Cubes, The (Tsumiki no ie) (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A gentle, elegiac miniature about memory and loss that touched me.

simulated_ratings.title: High Rollers (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A breezy caper whose charm is intermittent and stakes feel featherweight.

simulated_ratings.title: My Family (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere, sprawling generational drama—uneven, but heartfelt enough to carry me through.

simulated_ratings.title: Where's My Roy Cohn? (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A chilling, incisive expose that left me angry and newly clarified.

simulated_ratings.title: Hawks and Sparrows (Uccellacci e Uccellini) (1966)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Playful, prickly allegory more intellectually tickling than emotionally gripping for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Tree Grows in Brooklyn, A (1945)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, resilient family portrait that stung and warmed in equal measure.

simulated_ratings.title: Rabbit of Seville (1950)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A delightfully orchestrated burst of comic timing and musical wit that still sings.

simulated_ratings.title: Powers of Ten (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An elegant, mind-expanding visualization that made the abstract feel wonderfully clear.

simulated_ratings.title: His House (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An empathetic, haunting migration tale where the scares deepen the sorrow rather than cheapen it.
